title: 100 Batteries
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/EtRWR7zYxJ-batteries.jpg?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You go into your garage and find a pile of 100 batteries (all the same type)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You happen to know that half of them are good and half are bad, but you can't tell which is which."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You have a flashlight which uses two batteries, and requires both to work in order to turn on."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In the worst case scenario, with an optimal strategy, what is the minimum number of times you will need to put batteries into the flashlight before you can guarantee to get a working pair in the flashlight?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"text","text":"Details and Assumptions:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The flashlight either turns on or it doesn't, i.e. there is no way to distinguish between one of the two working and neither one working."}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Your answer should be the number of "flashlight loadings" you will need to actually get your flashlight working, not just how many you would need to identify two good batteries."}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Image credit:  https://www.slrlounge.com"}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You can do it with 53 "flashlight loadings" as follows:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Form 47 pairs of two, and try each one out."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"At this point, either the flashlight lit up (and you are done), or it didn't."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If it didn't, then at worse, there were 47 good batteries in the previous lot. So, you know that at least 3 of the remaining 6 are good."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, then divide these six up into 2 groups of 3 and one group is guaranteed to have a good pair in it."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, try each of the combinations within each group of three.  (That is six trials all together)  And, one is guaranteed to get the flashlight working!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"47+6 = \boxed{53}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thanks to @Brian Charlesworth for pointing out the error in my original solution which took 54 "flashlight loadings". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I will try to come up with a rigorous proof as to why you can't do it with fewer..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I suggest first proving that the best method will be a "partition and exhaust" method. (I don't know if there's an official name for that. By "partition and exhaust"  I mean partition the 100 batteries into 49 groups -- one fewer than the number of good batteries, cf. pigeonhole principle -- then perform a test on every possible pair within every one of those groups.) Once that is established, it's quite easy to verify that the number of tests is minimized by making the groups as "even" as possible, e.g. 47 size-two groups and 2 size-three groups is better than 48 size-two groups and 1 size-four group.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

Let us take the second scenario first.      For the worst case scenario we pick B from last pair, then test it with any of the previous pairs. We will fail twice thus making it 51.                                         "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First, you take any 4 of the batteries and check all 6 possible combinations. In the worst case scenario, they will all fail, determining that they were all bad batteries. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then, you take another 46 batteries and pair them into 23 groups. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Similarly, you take 46 batteries again and pair them into 23 groups. Again, all failed in worst case scenario. We know that we need at least 23 bad batteries for this to happen and look. 4+23+23 = 50."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We confirmed all the bad batteries in the pile. Therefore, the remaining 4 batteries must be all good ones and we can check any of them to finish the puzzle. 6+23+23+1 = 53."}]},{"type":"text","text":"
